bibl.title: Letter fragment to William Crawford Gorgas, July 3, 1911

div1.p: Gorgas has been offered the presidency of the University of Alabama.

div1.head: Letter fragment to William Crawford Gorgas, July 3, 1911
div1.p:
I have been trying to catch you somewhere between S.F. and
N.Y., and enlisted Dr. Ross to help me, but he couldn't wire anything
definite, except that you and Marie left Los Angeles Friday night and
probably left S.F. the next day.

We have been vastly stirred up and excited:- the Board of
Trustees of the Univ. met in Montgomery on Friday, and on Saturday we
had a long-distance message from Dr. Johnson, our friend on the Board,
saying that he was coming over to see us on a Very important matter.
At 9:30 P.M. two trustees drove up, in time to save the family from
nervous prostration, and said that Dr. Abercrombie had resigned the Pres-
idency,-resignation requested,- and that the Board tendered you the
Presidency of the Univ. by a unanimous vote, and until your decision
was learned, no other name will be even considered. Dr. Johnson was very
anxious to meet you in Chicago, so I at once sent a night letter to
Dr. Ross, trying to find out the train and route by which you left, but
could get no definite data, and had to long-distance Dr. Johnson today to
that effect. He will have a letter and telegram to meet you in N.Y.
but I promised to write you also on the subject.

Dr. Johnson told me privately that they could offer you
$7500 or even $8000 a year: a house, lights, fuel, and allowance for
entertaining, and other perquisites. The three summer months you would
be free to spend where you pleased, of course; your opportunity for
building up the university and making a name among educators would be
immense, and its by all odds the biggest thing the State can offer,
-2-
not excepting the Governorship. It occurs to me that if you and
Goethals are going to fall out, and you are to be thrown back on your
army salary, it might be worth your while to consider this. You could
get retired,-thirty years service,- and your retired pay, with this
salary as President, would be a pretty big thing down here. The
trustees say that it would almost certainly be a life position and
they are willing to do almost anything you ask to get you here. At
first blush will think as I did, that you can't even consider it,
but as I think it over the idea grows more and more attractive. I
have no fear of your success in the position; I know that you would
make a reputation for yourself in this line, as you have done in
in Tuscaloosa; a handsome house with all conveniences and her summers
she could almost spend away -- of course we are too interested to be
worth much as suggestors; it would be too entirely delightful to have
you all near us not to be alluring, but we all feel that you couldn't
come without sacrifice of inclination and perhaps some material loss,
and we haven't encouraged the trustees to hope that you may accept.

If you decline, let them understand your appreciation: they
are trying to confer on you the greatest gift in their power,-one
that any man in Alabama would be pleased to have tendered, even if
acceptance were out of the question. They may send a delegation on to
interview you, so be your most gracious self, that's all we ask.

Were I certain of your movements, as to whether or not you
and Marie stop in Washington. I might try to meet you there to talk
this over, am strongly tempted to come on to N.Y., but its a long, hot
trip for one day of talkey-talk.
